newsitem.title: PARAGUAY: LatAm trade union chiefs sound warning on Mercosur.
newsitem.headline: LatAm trade union chiefs sound warning on Mercosur.

text.p: The Latin American Workers Federation (CLAT) warned Tuesday that the customs union Mercosur is neglecting social policy.
"We want Mercosur to be profitable, but with social justice," CLAT delegate Ramon Ermacora told Reuters at the start of a summit in Paraguay.
"We don't want integration with greater unemployment, with hundreds of thousands living in poverty," said Ermacora.

Mercosur was launched in January by Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay. Chile signed up in July as an associate partner while similar deals are being sought by Andean Group nations Bolivia, Venezuela, Colombia, Peru and Ecuador.
The CLAT meeting, which aims to create a council of Mercosur workers, is being attended by trade union chiefs from Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay, Paraguay, Chile, Bolivia, Venezuela and Belgium.

"We're worried about Mercosur having too strong a focus on business, about it doing whatever it takes to deregulate and dismantle anything that hampers business, placing everything at the service of blind, heartless capital," said Ermacora.
"We're betting on Mercosur, but we're critical and think changes must be made to allow for social policy," he said.
Through its 41 member organizations and 15 associated regional federations, CLAT represents an estimated 22 million workers on the continent.
